usefulItems: metal bowl, piping bag and plain nozzle, dessert glasses, refrigerator
title: Piped Raspberry Mousse

ingredients.content: 60 g egg whites, from medium eggs

preparations.content: Soak gelatine leaves in a bowl of cold water. Meanwhile, place raspberry purée, lemon juice and Kirsch in mixing bowl then heat <b>5 min/90°C/speed 2<b>.
Squeeze out gelatine leaves, add to mixing bowl then mix <b>20 sec/speed 1<b>. Transfer to a large metal bowl then refrigerate. Clean mixing bowl.
Place a small bowl on mixing bowl lid then weigh in 100 g sugar. Remove bowl from lid.

<b>Insert butterfly whisk.<b> Place egg whites and salt in mixing bowl then, without measuring cup, whisk <b>9 min/70°C/speed 3<b>. With 5 minutes remaining, slowly add reserved sugar. Transfer to a bowl and set aside. Clean mixing bowl and butterfly whisk.
<b>Insert butterfly whisk.<b> Place cream in mixing bowl and whip <b>speed 3<b> until lightly whipped, watching carefully to avoid over-whipping.
Place chilled raspberry mixture over a bowl of ice until it starts to thicken (see tip). Fold through meringue and whipped cream. Pipe into glasses and refrigerate until ready to decorate and serve.

hintsAndTricks: To make your own raspberry purée, blend <b>350 g<b> fresh raspberries <b>30 sec/speed 9<b>, then pass through a fine sieve to remove seeds.
Using a metal bowl allows you to chill the raspberry mixture faster.
A good sign of a mixture thickening is that it leaves a trail that holds it's shape momentarily when you drizzle it back into the bowl from a spoon.
